titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Jesse Ely Wills Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

bioghist.head: Biography/Scope and Content Note
bioghist.p: Jesse Ely Wills, 1899-1977, a Nashville native, was a member of the group of poets who met in Nashville in the early 1920's to write and publish the influential literary magazine The Fugitive. He was an officer and executive of the National Life and Accident Insurance Company during his business career and was active in Vanderbilt University affairs as a member of the Board of Trust and chairman of the Board of the Joint University Libraries.
This collection contains literary correspondence, poems, and manuscripts of poet and businessman Jesse Ely Wills.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Outgoing. 1952-77. Arranged chronologically. 484 letters, the bulk of which consists of typed carbons. Folders 1-6.
Correspondence - Incoming. 1951-76. 492 letters, most typed, many holograph. Six postcards, three Christinas cards. Two telegrams. Arranged alphabetically according to sender. Folders 7-14.

Enclosures - Miscellaneous essays and reviews by Jesse E. Wills, newspaper clippings, photographs of Robert Penn Warren bust, essays by others, reprint essays of others, items showing his relationship with Allen Tate, miscellaneous papers. Folders 15-21.
Old Oak and Coffee House Papers 1930-1969, including drafts and later supplements to the papers. Folder 1.
Early and Late - Rough drafts, intermediate and final drafts, typescript (printer's 'copy), page proofs, business correspondence, congratulatory correspondence, reviews. Folders 1-6.
Notes, remarks on poetry readings. Folder 7.
Introduction of Jesse E. Wills on occasion of a poetry reading, 12 November 1971, by Frances Neel Cheney. Folder 8.
Tapes of poetry reading by Jesse E. Wills. 12 November 1971, 14 November 1973. Script of WPLN broadcast with Lin Folk, 8 April 1977. Folder 9.
Meditations on the American Indian - Drafts, typescript (printer's copy), page proofs, published copy in paper cover. Folders 10-12.
Conversation Piece - Notes and early drafts, intermediate and final drafts, page proofs, analytical letter from Donald Davidson. Folders 1-5.
Nashville and Other Poems - Notes and early drafts, intermediate and final drafts, typescript (printer's copy), page proofs. Folders 6-11.
Selected Poems - Early drafts, page proofs, correspondence» reviews. Folders 1-3.
á. Diversity of Interests - Draft copies, typescript, printer's copy, correspondence, essays not included in the publication, published copy in paper covers. Folders 4-9.
"First Lady" - Several drafts of a contemplated poem on Mrs. John F. Kennedy. Not completed. Folder 11.

Vanderbilt affiliations - Correspondence and reports concerning committee work. List of Committees follows: Academic Programs Committee. Folders 1-3. Ad hoc Committee on Composition of Undergraduate Student Body. .Folder 4. Committee for Fort Flowers Wing Dedication. Folder 5. Committee on Naming Buildings. Folder 6. Committee on Strengthening Athletics. Folder 7. Educational Programs Committee. Folder 8. Ethiopian Microfilming Project. Folder 9. Fraternity Study Committee. Folder 10. Graduate School of Management. Folder 11. JUL Building Fund. Folder 12. JUL Fugitive Room. Folder 13. Lawson Case. Folder 14. Long-Range Financial Planning Committee. Folder 15.

List of Committees continued: Ponzine, Raymond E. and Huber, Donald C. - Poetry Reading at Vanderbilt. Folder 16. Resolutions on the death of Vanderbilt Associates. Folder 17. Telecast of Basketball Games. Folder 18. W.R. Wills Center for Psychiatric Treatment and Research. Folder 19.
Correspondence is listed chronologically. Folder indicated by abbreviation F.

10 January to Robert Penn Warren; F. 1-6.

Memorandum on Fugitive Room in the New Wing of the Joint University Library; F. 6-13. This is a name index of the correspondents of Jesse Ely Wills. The figure (or figures) in parentheses immediately following each name denotes the total number of letters from that person in the collection; the dates are for the time of the letters. The full name of the writer is given whenever possible. The last number given refers to the box and folder in which the correspondence may be found.
